para.paratext: Historically, there were two important areas where the judge left the final determination of disputed facts concerning admissibility of evidence to the jury: confessions[1] and dying declarations.[2] In Jackson v. Denno,[3] the United States Supreme Court considered the three rules used by state and federal courts to determine voluntariness of confessions. The trial court's finding as to factual determinations and credibility of a witness relating to the admissibility of a defendant's statement at a Jackson-Denno hearing will be upheld, unless clearly erroneous.[4] Using the “orthodox” rule, the judge rules on the voluntariness of the confession for the purpose of admissibility after hearing all the evidence. The jury may consider evidence on voluntariness as affecting weight or credibility of the confession, but may not disregard the confession. Under the “New York” rule, the judge rules only that there has been a prima facie showing of voluntariness and leaves all factual conflict to be resolved by the jury. This was the rule the Georgia courts followed. A judge following the “Massachusetts” rule hears all the evidence and rules on the issue of voluntariness. However, the jury is instructed that it must also find the confession to be voluntary before it can consider it.

Jackson v. Denno was a habeas corpus attack in federal court on a New York confession. The United States Supreme Court held that a defendant has a constitutional right to a fair hearing and reliable determination on the voluntariness of his confession and that the New York procedure denied him due process under the Fourteenth Amendment. This ruling invalidated the Georgia procedure existing at the time.[5] The court approved both the “orthodox” and the Massachusetts rules with an obvious preference for the “orthodox” rule. In 1967, the Georgia Supreme Court approved the Massachusetts rule,[6] which requires the judge to hear all the evidence and make a definite finding of voluntariness before receiving a confession in evidence. The jury charge would include a statement that the court had made a finding that the confession was voluntary.

Subsequently, the court considered this procedure in Batts v. State.[7] Justice Hill explained the Georgia procedure as follows: “Thus, the present practice in Georgia may be described as following the orthodox rule, except that by timely written request to charge the defendant can invoke the Massachusetts rule. In the absence of such a request to charge, the court below followed the orthodox rule and made the required reliable determination as to the voluntariness of the confession.”

In Grant-Farley v. State,[8] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the trial court sits as the fact finder in a Jackson-Denno hearing. However, the court should not then announce its ruling to the jury. In Chumley v. State,[9] the trial court conducted a Jackson v. Denno hearing outside the presence of the jury, and then instructed the jury “the Court has ruled that the defendant clearly understood his rights, knew he was giving them up, and that his statement was clearly voluntary.” The Georgia Court of Appeals found that this was reversible plain error[10] and held, “A trial court's ruling before the jury on the voluntariness of a defendant's statement, even when coupled with an explanation as to the roles played by the trial court and the jury when the voluntariness of a defendant's statement is questioned, amounts to a violation of O.C.G.A. § 17-8-57.”[11]

In Burden v. State,[12] the Court of Appeals held that the trial court did not commit error in denying the defendant's motion to suppress evidence of his confession where the interviewing detective told the defendant he might garner sympathy by being honest and forthcoming. The court held that such exhortations to tell the truth are not a hope of benefit that renders a confession inadmissible.[13] The Court of Appeals likewise allowed a confession where the detective told the defendant he was “getting pissed off” as the words did not amount to a threat that would give rise to such fear of injury, and therefore the confession was not the result of intimidation or threats.[14] Likewise, the Court of Appeals allowed a confession when a child had first invoked his Miranda rights, but when asked immediately thereafter by the detective if he wanted to talk, the child stated “yes.”[15]

However, the Supreme Court has held that where the defendant is promised benefits, such as no incarceration, then the trial court must determine whether or not subsequent confessions, even when made after the initial statements, are tainted and should be excluded.[16] However, police statements that make a defendant aware of potential legal consequences do not constitute a threat.[17] The Court of Appeals has held a confession involuntary where a jail employee confessed to bringing drugs into the jail after the investigator led her to believe she would lose her job if she did not respond to his questions.[18]

But in Holcomb v. State,[19] the court applied the New York test as to a dying declaration. The trial judge made only a prima facie determination and left the final determination to the jury. This seems questionable. The trial judge said that he would charge as to the dying declaration and his failure to do so was harmful error.
Phillips v. State, 206 Ga. 418, 57 S.E.2d 555 (1950); Smith v. State, 218 Ga. 216, 126 S.E.2d 789 (1962); Lemon v. State, 80 Ga. App. 854, 57 S.E.2d 626 (1950).
Johnson v. State, 301 Ga. 707, 804 S.E.2d 38 (2017).

The majority opinion in Jackson v. Denno stated that it was unclear whether Georgia followed the Massachusetts or New York procedure. Jackson v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368, 379, 396, 84 S. Ct. 1774, 1782, 1791, 12 L. Ed. 2d 908, 917, 927, 1 A.L.R.3d 1205 (1964). Mr. Justice Black lists Georgia as following the New York procedure. Jackson v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368, 415, 84 S. Ct. 1774, 1801, 12 L. Ed. 2d 908, 938, 1 A.L.R.3d 1205 (1964).

In Sims v. State, 221 Ga. 190, 144 S.E.2d 103 (1965), the majority of the court sought to distinguish the Georgia procedure from the New York procedure. This case was reversed in Sims v. State of Ga., 385 U.S. 538, 87 S. Ct. 639, 17 L. Ed. 2d 593 (1967) which held that the Georgia procedure was like the New York procedure and invalid under Jackson v. Denno.
If there is no objection to voluntariness, no Jackson v. Denno hearing need be held. Day v. Mills, 224 Ga. 741, 164 S.E.2d 828 (1968); Watson v. State, 227 Ga. 698, 182 S.E.2d 446 (1971).
Voluntariness need only be shown by a preponderance of the evidence. High v. State, 233 Ga. 153, 210 S.E.2d 673 (1974).

In Lee v. State, 145 Ga. App. 369, 243 S.E.2d 734 (1978), at a Jackson v. Denno hearing, the trial judge said that the question of whether or not the confession was voluntary was an issue for the jury. This was error. Under the Massachusetts rule, the trial judge must make a ruling.
Scott v. State, 243 Ga. 233, 253 S.E.2d 698 (1979), held that when a statement of the defendant is used only for impeachment, a Jackson v. Denno hearing need not be held.

In Meyer v. State, 150 Ga. App. 613, 258 S.E.2d 217 (1979), the court again applied the incorrect rule that the state need only make a prima facie showing of voluntariness. In Stone v. State, 155 Ga. App. 357, 271 S.E.2d 22 (1980), the court returned to the proper rule.

In Jaheni v. State, 285 Ga. App. 266, 645 S.E.2d 735 (2007), the court held that a requirement for a hearing on the issue of voluntariness applies only if the evidence presents a fair question as to its voluntariness. Because the only evidence in the record was that the appellant's statements to the police were spontaneous, voluntary, and not made in response to interrogation, there was no error in the trial court's failure to conduct a hearing. When there is no dispute about what took place because both video and audio exist, the appellate court reviews de novo the trial court's determination of law and fact. Dozier v. State, 829 S.E.2d 131 (Ga. 2019).
Grant-Farley v. State, 292 Ga. App. 293, 664 S.E.2d 302 (2008).
Chumley v. State, 282 Ga. 855, 655 S.E.2d 813 (2008).

In Paul v. State, 272 Ga. 845, 537 S.E.2d 58 (2000) (disapproved of on other grounds by, Ledford v. State, 289 Ga. 70, 709 S.E.2d 239 (2011)), it was held that the “plain error” rule does not establish a different standard for determining the reversibility of an error, but instead allows a criminal defendant to avoid the penalty of waiver, by “permit[ting] appellate review of assertions of error raised for the first time on appeal where the asserted error affects substantive rights.” (citing Brooks v. State, 281 Ga. 514, 640 S.E.2d 280 (2007)).

In Golden v. State, 45 Ga. App. 501, 165 S.E. 299 (1932), it was held that “it is the duty of this Court to grant a new trial when such error is committed, whether, in its opinion, substantial justice has or has not been done by the verdict.”

O.C.G.A. § 17-8-57 states: “It is error for any judge in any criminal case, during its progress or in his charge to the jury, to express or intimate his opinion as to what has or has not been proved or as to the guilt of the accused. Should any judge violate this Code section, the violation shall be held by the Supreme Court or Court of Appeals to be error and the decision in the case reversed, and a new trial granted in the court below with such directions as the Supreme Court or Court of Appeals may lawfully give.” Ray v. State, 181 Ga. App. 42, 44, 351 S.E.2d 490 (1986), held that it is error to violate even the spirit of this section. Consequently, a violation is a mandatory cause for a new trial. See also Dean v. State, 168 Ga. App. 172, 308 S.E.2d 434 (1983).
However, it is not error to tell the jury why they had been segregated. Pierce v. State, 238 Ga. 682, 235 S.E.2d 374 (1977).

In Harper v. State, 171 Ga. App. 57, 318 S.E.2d 787 (1984), it was held that the trial court's explanation to jury, out of presence of defense counsel, of purpose of Jackson v. Denno hearing did not violate statute forbidding judge to express opinion as to what has been proved or as to defendant's guilt.
Burden v. State, 332 Ga. App. 811, 775 S.E.2d 183 (2015).

See also State v. Jackson, 332 Ga. App. 356, 772 S.E.2d 804 (2015) (overruled on other grounds by, State v. Andrade, 298 Ga. 464, 782 S.E.2d 665 (2016)); Baughns v. State, 335 Ga. App. 600, 782 S.E.2d 494 (2016).
Burden v. State, 332 Ga. App. 811, 775 S.E.2d 183 (2015).
In Interest of R. P., 346 Ga. App. 193, 816 S.E.2d 96 (2018).
State v. Chulpayev, 296 Ga. 764, 770 S.E.2d 808 (2015).
Blackwell v. State, 337 Ga. App. 173, 786 S.E.2d 552 (2016).
Zeigler v. State, 2019 WL 2559718 (Ga. Ct. App. 2019).
Holcomb v. State, 249 Ga. 658, 292 S.E.2d 839 (1982).
